Can he advise who was involved in the formulation of the application; if so, who.
Did the application comply with funding guidelines of the Federal Government Funding Authority.
What sum of funding was requested in the application.
On what date did applications (a) open, and (b) close.
Was the application lodged by the close date.
To whom was the application addressed.
Was he aware of the application; if not, why not.
Was the Federal Member for Eden Monaro advised of the application; if so, by whom and when.

talker.name: Albanese, Anthony, MP
talker.role: Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government
talker.name: Mr Albanese

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: and (2) This is a matter for the NSW Government.
N/A. The proposal was not submitted to any particular program. There was no request for applications from the Australian Government.
to (8) Refer to (3)
This is a matter for the Member for Eden Monaro.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Training and Support Team East Timor

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence Personnel, Materiel and Science, in writing, on 4 June 2009:

item.para: Is he aware of the ongoing campaign for formal public recognition of the Warlike Service (WLS) of the Australian Training and Support Team East Timor (ATST-EM).

Did the Government direct the Department of Defence to release a DEFGRAM on 26 March 2009 announcing the recognition of WLS for the ATST-EM; if so, who was the responsible Minister or Parliamentary Secretary.
What protocols, processes or legal requirements must be fulfilled to have the WLS of the ATSTEM publicly recognised.
Will he publicly announce recognition of WLS for ATST-EM veterans who served on active service in East Timor; if not, why not.
Does the award of a War Service Pension (WSP) to qualifying persons depend upon the formal public recognition of active WLS.
Is he aware that members of the ATST-EM who have qualified for a WSP, are having their applications denied due to a lack of public recognition of active service in East Timor; if not, why not.
Did the Deputy Chief of Army, at any stage, order ATST-EM members to return their United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor (UNTAET) medals; if so, why.
Have ATST-EM members been retrospectively awarded the UNTAET medal; if not, why not.

talker.name: Combet, Greg, MP
talker.role: Minister for Defence Personnel, Materiel and Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Climate Change
talker.name: Mr Combet

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.
No.
There are no protocols, processes or legal requirements that must be fulfilled to have the WLS of the ATST-EM publicly recognised.
No decision has been made to publicly announce recognition of WLS for ATST-EM veterans who served on active service in East Timor.

and (6) There is no requirement for public recognition to qualify for the award of the War Service Pension. Personnel wishing to access veterans’ entitlements associated with their service in ATST-EM can do so once Department of Veterans’ Affairs has confirmed their service with Defence.

I am advised that the Army understands that in 2001 an investigation was commissioned by the then Commander of the Australian Contingent – East Timor into how the Australian Training Support Team – East Timor received the UNTAET medal, as they were not assigned to the United Nations. In 2003, it is further understood that a direction was issued that the medals had been issued in error and that they be withdrawn. Action was initiated by the Army to comply with this direction.
The UNTAET Medal can only be authorised for issue by the Security Council of the United Nations.

In July 2008, the Vice Chief of the Defence Force wrote to the United Nations Headquarters Military Adviser, Lieutenant General Chikadibia Obiakor, requesting that he, as the delegate for the award of the United Nations medals, agree to the retrospective award of the UNTAET Medal to the 205 members of the ATST-EM who served during the period 1 March 2001 to 25 July 2005.
Defence was passed a response from the United Nations dated 23 December 2008 advising that the United Nations Secretariat has not approved retrospective award of the medal to ATST-EM members.

There are no further avenues available to Defence to influence the award of the UNTAET Medal to ATST-EM members, although individuals may apply to the United Nations for reconsideration of their specific circumstance.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 4 June 2009:

para.inline: In respect of the Government’s changes to the 457 Visa Program, and its announcement on 15 May 2009 that labour agreements aim to provide a flexible response to the needs of industries experiencing skills shortages:

item.label: (a)
item.para: what is the average length of time taken for labour agreements to be approved;

item.label: (b)
item.para: how is the process considered to be flexible for those employers who experience skills shortages; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: how many 457 visa holders are in South Australia; and of these, how many have indicated they are willing to relocate to remote areas such as Coober Pedy in pursuit of training and employment.

talker.name: Rudd, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr Rudd

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The time taken to finalise a labour agreement can vary considerably depending on the complexity of the agreement; the number and type of concessions sought, the quality of the information provided and the response times of the employer. It generally takes around four months to prepare a labour agreement, and they can be finalised in about four weeks following provision of the required documentation. In exceptional circumstances, it can take up to two years to finalise an agreement.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The standard Subclass 457 sponsorship arrangement allows sponsors to nominate only people with occupations that are on an occupation list approved for this program. Labour agreements provide flexibility by allowing employers experiencing skills shortages in other occupations or approved occupations who cannot meet the full requirements for the standard Subclass 457 sponsorship arrangement, to negotiate with the Commonwealth approval to nominate skilled overseas workers.

item.label: (c)
item.para: There were 2,950 primary visa holders in South Australia at 30 April 2009. The Department of Immigration and Citizenship does not collect data that would indicate whether a visa holder is willing to relocate to more remote areas in pursuit of training and employment.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 4 June 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Government’s changes to the 457 Visa Program, and its announcement on 15 May 2009 that labour agreements aim to provide a flexible response to the needs of industries experiencing skills shortages:

item.label: (a)
item.para: have any applications for 457 visas been refused as a result of the changes; if so, how many;

item.label: (b)
item.para: why is the scheme not being introduced in 2010; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: do transitional arrangements exist to (i) provide employers with time to arrange labour agreements, and (ii) allow 457 visa applications received prior to the changes to be processed in accordance with the requirements under the old program; if not, why not.

talker.name: Rudd, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Prime Minister
talker.name: Mr Rudd

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Since the announcement, there has been one nomination refused as a result of this change.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The scheme was introduced as part of the package of reforms to the Subclass 457 visa program. The changes are being rolled out when the legislation and systems changes can be made. This change required minor alterations and could be implemented earlier than some other changes.

item.label: (c) (i)
item.para: No. (ii) No. The changed arrangements require all applications not finalised on 15 May 2009 to pursue a labour agreement. Applicants who have an existing application not finalised under standard business sponsorship provisions are invited to withdraw their applications and seek a refund of the fee. The government introduced the changes to ensure that employers using the Subclass 457 visa program to access ASCO 5-7 occupations satisfy obligations on local training and employment.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 4 June 2009:

quote.para: In respect of her media release of 2 June 2009 relating to the numbers of Australians taking-up the First Home Owners Grant Boost:

item.para: For each month between 1 October 2008 and 30 April 2009, how many grants were given for (a) new construction ($21,000), and (b) existing homes ($14,000).

Can she indicate, for each month between 1 October 2008 and 30 April 2009 and in percentage terms, what proportion of grants delivered by each State and territory government comprise the (a) $21,000 for new constructed housing, and (b) $14,000 for sales of existing housing; if not, why not.

talker.name: Swan, Wayne, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Swan

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The breakdown between the take-up of First Home Owners Boost grants for established housing and for new homes is not publicly available.

As the First Home Owners Scheme is a state- and territory-based scheme, publication of the number of recipients of the $7,000 First Home Owners Scheme grant is a matter for the States and Territories.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 15 June 2009:

item.para: In respect of the now fully operational Child Care Management System (CCMS), for each week for the period 4 May 2009 to 1 June 2009: (a) for how many children did the Government provide the Child Care Benefit (CCB); (b) what was the breakdown, by age, of children in approved care; (c) what was the total cost to the Government of the CCB; (d) what was the total number of reported centre vacancies; and (e) what was the breakdown, by postcode, of centre vacancies.
What proportion of total Government spending on the CCB is provided for (a) approved, and (b) registered, care.
On average, how many claims for the CCB are made each week for registered care.
What is the Government’s most recent data on average weekly child care costs.
Does she intend to release the results of her department’s November 2008 Survey of Child Care Services; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (1) (a) (b)
item.para: & (c) Child Care Benefit (CCB) information captured in the Child Care Management System (CCMS) is not currently available for the period of 4 May 2009 to 1 June 2009.

item.label: (d)
item.para: & (e) Aggregated information on reported child care vacancies is not available.
In March quarter 2008, approved care accounted for 99.4% of total quarterly CCB expenditure. Registered care accounted for 0.6% of the total quarterly CCB expenditure.
On average there are approximately 2,850 families that claimed registered care for approximately 3,260 children per week in March quarter 2008.

The most recent data on average weekly child care costs show that in September quarter 2008, the average cost per family was $79.51 after CCB fee reduction. Most families are able to receive 50% of these costs back through the Child Care Tax Rebate, dependent on fulfilling work-study-training requirements.
Results from the November 2008 Survey of Child Care Service Providers are available on the DEEWR website:
http://www.deewr.gov.au/EarlyChildhood/Resources/Documents/2009SupplementaryTables.pdf

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Tourism, in writing, on 16 June 2009:

quote.para: In respect of his proposed transfer of Tourism Research Australia (TRA) from the auspices of Tourism Australia to his department—

item.para: On what advice did he make the decision to transfer TRA.
On what date did he advise (a) his department, and (b) Tourism Australia, of his intention to transfer TRA.
On what date will the transfer occur.
As at 16 June 2009, how many staff were employed by TRA.
Does he foresee a reduction in the number of staff employed by (a) TRA, and (b) Tourism Australia, as a result of the transfer; if so, how many staff of (a) and (b) will lose their jobs.
What appropriations have been allocated for the cost of the transfer.
Did he ever rescind his direction to transfer TRA; if so, on what date and how.

talker.name: Ferguson, Martin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Resources and Energy and Minister for Tourism
talker.name: Mr Martin Ferguson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: My decision to transfer TRA was made on the basis of a range of advice, including feedback from industry.
I communicated my intention to the Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism on 25 February 2009. I advised the TA Chair, Rick Allert AO on 29 April 2009.
The intention is to have the transfer take effect as soon as practicable.
No.
There is no additional appropriation required to effect the transfer.
I have not issued a direction to transfer TRA.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 17 June 2009:

item.para: What is the total monetary value of work associated with the decontamination of land at the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site.

Did the department have any agreement, financial or otherwise, with Richmond Valley Council concerning the decontamination of land at the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site; if so, what did the agreement include.
Did Richmond Valley Council contribute to the cost of decontaminating land at the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site; if so, what sum of money did it contribute.
On what date did the decontamination work at the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site begin; what stage is it currently at; and by what date is it due for completion.
Does the department have any remaining (a) financial, and (b) land title, interests at the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site; if so, what are they.
On what date was the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site given to the Richmond Valley Council.
Does the department retain any rights in respect of the use of the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome site; if so, what do these rights entail.
What were the original boundaries of the Evans Head Memorial Airfield during World War II.

talker.name: Combet, Greg, MP
talker.role: Minister for Defence Personnel, Materiel and Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Climate Change
talker.name: Mr Combet

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.para: Responsibility for the package of remediation works being undertaken at Evans Head Aerodrome is the responsibility of the Richmond Valley Council. Defence has agreed to assist Council with part of the remediation costs associated with this site to a limit of $1.8 million.
Yes. Defence has an agreement with the Richmond Valley Council to contribute $1.8million toward the costs for remediation of the land set aside for an Aged Care Facility.
Yes. Richmond Valley Council has committed to fund remediation work at the Aged Care Facility site. Tenders for the work have not yet been called so the cost is not known at this stage.
Remediation of the Aged Care Facility site is not due to commence until February 2010. The work is expected to be completed by the end of June 2010.

item.label: (5) (a)
item.para: and (b) No.

In 1992 ownership of the Aerodrome passed from the then Commonwealth Department of Transport to Richmond River Shire Council (now Richmond Valley Council) under an Airport Local Ownership Plan agreement.
No.

Richmond Valley Council has advised Defence that to the best of its knowledge, the boundaries of the Evans Head Memorial Aerodrome during World War II are described in Lot 2 Deposited Plan 214941 dating from 1962.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Air Force: Learmonth Base

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 23 June 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Learmonth Base, Western Australia: (a) will an increase in commercial passenger air movement affect RAAF operations; (b) on what date will the current lease arrangements between the Commonwealth and the Shire of Exmouth expire; and (c) what are the critical issues determining an extension or renewal of this lease.

talker.name: Combet, Greg, MP
talker.role: Minister for Defence Personnel, Materiel and Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Climate Change
talker.name: Mr Combet

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: A modest increase in the number of civil flights (i.e. a few per day) at RAAF Learmonth would have minimal effect on the Air Force’s operations.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Exmouth Shire was granted a 30 year lease that commenced on 8 March 1993 and expires on 7 March 2023.

item.label: (c)
item.para: The current lease is not compliant with the Airports Act 1996 and will not be extended. If the Shire of Exmouth require a lease beyond 2023, a new compliant lease will be required. The lease will also need to address issues associated with the use of Defence infrastructure such as runway usage and the management of aircraft operations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, in writing, on the 23 June 2009:

item.para: On average, how much (a) natural gas based energy is consumed per calendar year in compressing natural gas so it can travel throughout the Australian domestic natural gas pipeline network, and (b) Carbon Dioxide (CO2) emissions are produced in part (a).
What advice has he received on how these CO2 emissions might be reduced other than by increasing the price of natural gas for consumers.

talker.name: Ferguson, Martin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Resources and Energy and Minister for Tourism
talker.name: Mr Martin Ferguson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian pipeline network includes high pressure transmission and low pressure distribution components. The National Inventory Team, part of the Department of Climate Change, compiles emissions data for the purposes of producing the National Greenhouse Accounts. As part of this, it estimates emissions and fuel use separately for high pressure gas transmission and low pressure gas distribution networks. It advised that in 2006-07, the energy use in high pressure natural gas transmission totalled 17 PJ (resulting in 858 kilotonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions). The additional energy use in national gas production and low pressure distribution totalled 6 PJ (resulting in 320 kilotonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions). While the latter figure is not disaggregated, approximately two-thirds (4 PJ) is used in gas distribution.
The Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism has not provided any advice to Minister Ferguson on how these emissions might be reduced.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: In respect of reposted AusTender Contract Notices CN187855 to CN189059—

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

quote.para: Attachment A is provided in response to question 1 (a), (b) and (c).

Not all original postings were published within six weeks of the contract start date due to inconsistency of practices in the former DEST and DEWR and the financial and reporting system capabilities – issues which have now been addressed.
The names of contract vendors for contracts that were published outside the CPG guidelines are at Attachment B.
Attachment A: Listing of Austender records CN187855 to CN189059 is available from the House of Representatives Table Office.
Attachment B: Listing of Austender records published after six weeks after engagement is available from the House of Representatives Table Office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Attachment A is provided in response to the question part (a) and Attachment B is provided in response to part (b) of the question.
Attachment A: Listing of republished Austender records is available from the House of Representatives Table Office.
Attachment B: Listing of Austender records not republished is available from the House of Representatives Table Office.

subdebateinfo.title: Disability Employment Services and Employer Incentives Scheme

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Participation, in writing on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Disability Employment Services and Employer Incentives Scheme 2010–12, what is the key date for (a) the Invitation to Treat, (b) issuing the Request for Tender, (c) the close of tender, and (d) the announcement of successful tenderers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Government’s Aviation Green Paper released in December 2008 and his associated media release of 19 June 2009: (a) has he commenced a site investigation process for a second Sydney airport, in conjunction with the New South Wales Government; (b) given that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) National Platform specifically rules out a second Sydney airport from being developed within the Sydney Basin, and the consultation draft National Platform to be considered at the 2009 ALP National Conference has removed this requirement, will the Government still consider building a second airport within the Sydney Basin; and (c) in respect of aviation policy, what is the Government’s interpretation of the Sydney Basin.

talker.name: Albanese, Anthony, MP
talker.role: Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government
talker.name: Mr Albanese

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The Federal Government has invited the NSW Government to participate in a joint study to assess options, identify potential sites and evaluate investment strategies for delivering additional airport capacity for Sydney.
The final terms of reference for the joint study will be released later this year as part of the National Aviation White Paper.
Until the findings of the joint study are delivered, the Australian Government is not going to speculate on possible sites for a second Sydney airport.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

item.para: What evidence is there to justify claims that there are poor literacy levels among Australian school children?
Where is Australia placed on the most recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development comparison on the national literacy levels?

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: What evidence is there to justify claims that there are poor literacy levels among Australian school children?

In 2008, the National Assessment Program – Literacy and Numeracy (NAPLAN) commenced in Australian schools. The NAPLAN identifies student achievement of essential literacy and numeracy skills. A key part of this process is the identification of those students who have not achieved the minimum national standard for their year level and, who need further help to achieve the skills they require to continue in schooling.

The data from the NAPLAN test results gives schools and systems the ability to compare their students’ achievements against national standards and with student achievement in other states and territories. It also allows the monitoring of progress over time.

Results from the 2008 NAPLAN tests indicate that at the national level, across the literacy domains and year levels, on average about 80 per cent of students are above the national minimum standard, about 13 per cent are achieving at the national minimum standard and about 7 cent are below the national minimum standard.

For Indigenous students at the national level, across the literacy domains and year levels, on average about 44 per cent of Indigenous students are above the national minimum standard, about 23 per cent are achieving at the national minimum standard and about 33 per cent are below the national minimum standard.
The results for all year levels and domains can be found in the 2008 National Report at http://www.naplan.edu.au/.
Where is Australia placed on the most recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development comparison on national literacy levels?

57 countries participated in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) in 2006 and the results were released in December 2007.

Australia’s mean score for reading literacy in PISA 2006 was 513 points, above the OECD average of 492 points. This represented a statistically significant decline from Australia’s mean score in PISA 2003 of 525 points.

Australia was significantly outperformed by five countries in PISA 2006: Korea (556), Finland (547), Hong Kong-China (536), Canada (527) and New Zealand (521). Australia performed at a level with no statistically significant difference or not significantly different to Ireland, Liechtenstein, Poland, Sweden and the Netherlands and outperformed all other participating countries.
Australia was outperformed by only two countries, Finland and Korea, in PISA 2003.

The remaining 13 countries are all non-OECD (partner) countries

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Building the Education Revolution Program: (a) have any schools with transient enrolments, such as hospital schools, been provided with funding under the program; if not, why not; and (b) are schools with transient enrolments eligible for any other capital grants under other programs; if so, what are the details.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Funding under the Building the Education Revolution (BER) program is allocated based on full time enrolments at schools. As the students at schools with transient student populations are enrolled at other schools, funding has been provided to those other schools for those students, who are expected to return to their local school and so benefit from the funding. As such, no BER funding is available for schools with transient student populations.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Local Schools Working Together Program is aimed at partnerships to build shared educational facilities. The preferred partnership is between a government and non-government school but it may include a partnership within the educational sector along with a third party. Under this arrangement a school with a transient student population could be a partner with another school eligible to receive recurrent funding under the Schools Assistance Act 2008.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

item.para: What sum of money was provided to (a) government, and (b) non-government, schools in every electoral division for the 2007-08 and 2008-09 financial years.
What was the (a) expenditure on, (b) location of, and (c) purpose of, each grant in part (1).

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The government school detail requested in the question is not collected by the Department and is not available. The non-government data is not easily compiled and responding to this question would be an unreasonable diversion of the department’s resources.

Grant information for General Recurrent Grants (non-government schools only), Capital Grants and Investing in our Schools Program is published in the Green Report annually on a calendar year basis. The latest report is in respect of 2007 funding. Other grants to schools are published on the Department’s websites.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Building the Education Revolution program: (a) what action does her department take to resolve formal complaints; and (b) are there any complaint operating procedures and guidelines for the program; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Formal complaints about the Building the Education Revolution Program (BER) are received through an email inbox set up for the National BER Coordinator. Every complaint received by the BER Taskforce is investigated by Departmental officers. Replies are sent, wherever possible, within 24 hours.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The complaint operating procedures and guidelines for the BER make provision for responses to be provided to all complaints. Once complaints are received, they are registered and the National Coordinator is notified. The complaint is investigated by Departmental officers in consultation with the relevant state/territory education authority or Block Grant Authority and a response is prepared.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: Is the Government committed to funding distance education; if so, what are the full details of its commitment to public distance education providers.

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The Australian Government believes that every parent has the right to choose an education that best suits the needs of their child, irrespective of their religious beliefs. I acknowledge that regular schools are not available or may not be suitable for all children and therefore distance education fulfils a need.
The Government provides funding for distance education students that are using registered distance education facilities which are part of a registered non-government school.

The Australian Government provides funding for students educated at government schools under the National Education Agreement. It is each state and territory’s responsibility to determine its priorities in the provision of education, including distance education.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

item.para: For the calendar years 2006, 2007, 2008, and 2009: (a) what was the total number of school leavers enrolled in (i) Vocational Education and Training (VET), and (ii) university; and (b) what percentage of all school leavers enrolled in (i) VET, and (ii) university.
What sum was allocated in the 2009-10 Budget to (a) VET providers, including TAFE’s, and (b) universities?

talker.name: Gillard, Julia, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister for Social Inclusion
talker.name: Ms Gillard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Mr Pyne’s question is specific to ‘school leavers’. There is not a national administrative data collection of school leaver numbers, and hence percentages can not be derived as requested.

However the Australian Bureau of Statistics’ annual ‘Survey of Education and Work’ publishes estimates of school leavers aged 15 to 24 years, and their study destinations. The survey estimates that there were 302 100 school leavers in 2006, 303 100 in 2007, and 313 600 in 2008.

Enrolments at bachelor degree level or above were estimated at 82 600 in 2006, or 27.3 per cent of school leavers, at 83 600 in 2007 (27.6 per cent), and 83 900 in 2008 (26.8 per cent). Enrolments in vocational studies were estimated at 79 200 in 2006, or 26.2 per cent of school leavers, at 82 300 in 2007 (27.2 per cent), and 89 000 in 2008 (28.4 per cent).

item.label: (a)
item.para: In the 2009-10 Budget $2 657 482 000 was allocated for funding for training to VET Providers, including TAFE’s. This includes funding provided to states and territories to fund their VET training systems through the Inter Government Agreement on Federal Financial Relations and the VET infrastructure component of the Education Infrastructure Fund.

In prior years, under the Skilling Australia’s Workforce Act 2005 and the 2005-2008 Commonwealth-State Agreement for Skilling Australia’s Workforce, States and Territories were required to contribute base recurrent funding on a 2:1 ratio to Commonwealth government funding, plus match the Commonwealth on additional recurrent funding. All States and Territories met or exceeded this requirement during the period of the Skilling Australia’s Workforce Agreement.
Under the new Inter Government Agreement there is no specific requirement in terms of the amount to be contributed by States and Territories.

item.label: (b)
item.para: In the 2009-10 Budget $6 350 955 000 was allocated for 2009-10 for the higher education sector (including universities and other eligible bodies) through the Education, Employment and Workplace Relations portfolio. This excludes funding to universities through the Innovation, Industry, Science and Research portfolio.

This also excludes funding allocated for Commonwealth Scholarships administered by higher education providers, Higher Education Loan Program assistance for students and Education Investment Fund VET projects.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

item.para: As at 31 March 2009, how many (a) people were covered by private health insurance policies provided by an employer; and (b) businesses provided Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership for their employees.

Did his department or any other agency model the effect of the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy on businesses which provide Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership to employees

talker.name: Swan, Wayne, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Swan

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The number of employer-provided private health insurance policies is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits.

The effect of the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy on businesses which provide Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership to employees was not modelled due to information on the number and incomes of such employees not being available.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

item.para: Is his department able to estimate the additional annual increase in private health premium liabilities for businesses which provide Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership for their employees from 1 July 2010, due to the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy; if so, what is the quantum of those liabilities.

talker.name: Swan, Wayne, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Swan

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The increase in private health insurance premium liabilities for business cannot be quantified, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: Is his department able to estimate the additional annual Fringe Benefits Tax liabilities to businesses which provide Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership for employees from 1 July 2010 due to the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy; if so, what is the quantum of those liabilities.

talker.name: Swan, Wayne, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Swan

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The additional fringe benefit tax liability for businesses with employer-provided private health insurance policies is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: Is his department able to estimate how many businesses will no longer provide Fringe Benefits Tax-liable private health insurance membership for their employees from 1 July 2010 as a result of the increase in premium costs associated with the introduction of the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy; if so, how many.

talker.name: Swan, Wayne, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Swan

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The number of businesses who no longer provide private health insurance policies as a result of the policy is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: Is his department able to estimate how many people will no longer have their private health insurance membership provided by an employer from 1 July 2010 as a result of the introduction of the Fairer Private Health Insurance Incentives policy; if so, how many.

talker.name: Swan, Wayne, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Swan

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The number of people who no longer have employer-provided private health insurance policies as a result of the policy is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: What sum of Fringe Benefits Tax revenue from businesses which provide private health insurance membership to employees did the Government receive in 2007-08.

talker.name: Swan, Wayne, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Swan

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The fringe benefits tax revenue collected due to employer-provided private health insurance is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: What sum of Fringe Benefits Tax revenue from businesses which provide private health insurance membership to employees does the Government expect to receive in the 2008-09 and 2009-10 financial years.

talker.name: Swan, Wayne, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Swan

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The fringe benefits tax revenue collected due to employer-provided private health insurance is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘Other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, in writing, on 25 June 2009:

quote.para: What sum of Fringe Benefits Tax revenue does the Government expect to forfeit in the 2010-11 financial year as a result of businesses reducing their provision of private health insurance membership to employees.

talker.name: Swan, Wayne, MP
talker.role: Treasurer
talker.name: Mr Swan

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The change in fringe benefits tax revenue collected in the 2010-11 financial year due to any changes in the provision of employer-provided private health insurance is unquantifiable, as this type of fringe benefit is not separately identified on fringe benefits tax returns submitted by businesses. Private health insurance fringe benefits fall into the ‘other benefits (residual)’ category on the fringe benefits tax return, along with various other types of fringe benefits.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment, Heritage and the Arts: Staffing

quote.para: In respect of his Ministerial staff:

What are the details of their (a) classification, (b) salary, and (c) when they commenced working with him.
What are the details concerning staff who have left his employment, including when.

talker.name: Garrett, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts
talker.name: Mr Garrett

quote.para: The information below was provided by the Department of Finance and Deregulation, as at 25 June 2009. Classifications and salary ranges only are provided so as not to identify personal information of individual employees.

entry.para: 1 x Senior Adviser (Chief of Staff – Cabinet)

item.para: No personal staff have ceased employment.
